content.title: COMPLETING THE SQUARE
content.content: Suppose we want to graph the quadratic function y = x^2 - 4x + 1. This function is not written in the form y = (x - h)^2 + k, but we can convert it into this form by completing the square.

example.conclusion: So, the graph of y = x^2 - 4x + 1 can be found by translating y = x^2 2 units to the right and 3 units downwards.

content.title: AXES INTERCEPTS
content: An x-intercept of a function is a value of x where its graph meets the x-axis. x-intercepts are found by letting y be 0 in the equation of the function.
A y-intercept of a function is a value of y where its graph meets the y-axis. y-intercepts are found by letting x be 0 in the equation of the function.

content.title: THE y-INTERCEPT
content.theorem: For a quadratic function in the form y = ax^2 + bx + c, the y-intercept is the constant term c.
content.proof: If x = 0 then y = a(0)^2 + b(0) + c, therefore y = c

content.title: THE x-INTERCEPTS
content.theorem: For a quadratic function in the form y = a(x - α)(x - β), the x-intercepts are α and β.
content.proof: If y = 0 then a(x - α)(x - β) = 0, therefore x = α or β {since a ≠ 0}
content.note: x-intercepts are therefore easy to find when the quadratic is in factorised form.

content.title: FACTORISING TO FIND x-INTERCEPTS
content.theorem: For any quadratic function of the form y = ax^2 + bx + c, the x-intercepts can be found by solving the equation ax^2 + bx + c = 0.

content.title: AXIS OF SYMMETRY
content.content: The graphs of all quadratic functions are symmetrical about a vertical line passing through the vertex. This line is called the axis of symmetry.
content.note: If the graph has two x-intercepts, then the axis of symmetry is midway between them.
content.equation_form: The equation of a vertical line has the form x = k.

content.title: AXIS OF SYMMETRY FORMULA
content.content: If the quadratic does not have any x-intercepts, or if we do not know the x-intercepts, we can use the rule below to find the axis of symmetry:
content.formula: The equation of the axis of symmetry of y = ax^2 + bx + c is x = -b/(2a).

derivation.conclusion: The horizontal shift from y = ax^2 to y = ax^2 + bx + c is -b/(2a) units, therefore the axis of symmetry of y = ax^2 + bx + c has equation x = -b/(2a).
